Flip a fair coin 100 timesâ€”it gives a sequence of heads (H) and tails (T). For each HH in the sequence of flips, Alice gets a point; for each HT, Bob does, so e.g. for the sequence THHHT Alice gets 2 points and Bob gets 1 point. Who is most likely to win? (https://x.com/littmath/status/1769044719034647001)


```{r}
library(stringr)

flipSim <- function(){
  Alice = 0
  Bob = 0
  myFlips = sample(c('H','T'), size=100, replace=T)
  myString =  paste0(myFlips, collapse="")
  for (i in 1:99){
    myTuple = substring(myString,i, i+1)
    if (myTuple == "HH"){Alice=Alice+1}
    if(myTuple == "HT"){Bob = Bob+1}
  }
  
  
  if(Alice > Bob){myOut='Alice'}
  if (Bob>Alice){myOut='Bob'}
  if(Bob==Alice){myOut="Tie"}
  
  return(myOut)
  }

mySims <- replicate(1000,flipSim())

sum(mySims=='Bob')/1000
sum(mySims=="Alice")/1000
sum(mySims=="Tie")/1000



```
